results.title: Reunion in France
results.creator_credit: Jules Dassin, Joseph L Mankiewicz and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Frenchwoman Michele de la Becque (Joan Crawford) is a pampered Parisian whose high society lifestyle abruptly changes with the Nazi invasion of Paris. A downed RAF pilot on the run - Pat Talbot (John Wayne), enters her world seeking asylum, which Michele provides by hiding him in her tiny apartment. His escape however is reliant on the co-operation of Michele’s rich industrialist finace Robert Corlot (Phillip Dorn) - who may also be a Nazi collaborator, a situation which is fraught with danger when love and allegiance are on the line. Cast also includes Reginald Owen, Albert Bassermann and John Carradine.

results.title: Return to the sea: a saga of survival
results.creator_credit: Martin McGrath, Ian McFadyen and Comedia
results.brief_description: A humorous parody of David Attenborough’s “Life on earth” documentaries. Our suburban mode of existence with its annual return to the beach resorts is likened to the ritualistic behaviour of members of the animal kingdom. Raises issues about the way we define the behaviour of cultures different from our own. Contains an early performance by Steve Vizard.

results.title: Return to Sandakan
results.creator_credit: Raymond Quint, Japan Foundation and Film Australia National Interest Program
results.brief_description: During World War II, Sandakan prisoner of war camp in British North Borneo held nearly 2,500 Allied prisoners. By war’s end, only six survived. The story of the atrocities committed by the Japanese at Sandakan is one of the grimmest of the Pacific War. Shot in Australia, Malaysia and Japan, this documentary recounts the tragic story of prisoners of war and examines the legacy of these events for survivors and their families. Some of the images in this program may be disturbing to some viewers.

results.title: Return to Oz
results.creator_credit: Walter Murch, Paul Maslansky and Oz Productions
results.brief_description: Based on L. Frank Baum’s two follow-up books to The Wizard of Oz, “Return to Oz” is not quite the frolicking musical fantasy of the original family film and it may prove a bit too scary for the younger viewer. Dorothy (Fairuza Balk), since returning home from the Land of Oz, cannot clear her head of the wonderful adventures and amazing characters she had come to know and love. Auntie Em, determined to rid Dorothy of all this Oz nonsense, sends her off for psychiatric treatment at a sanitarium. However, Dorothy is rescued by a mysterious girl and just as mysteriously ends up back in the Land of Oz where all is not as it was and the magical fantasy begins to turn into a nightmare adventure. Cast includes Nicol Williamson, Jean Marsh, Piper Laurie, Matt Clark. Parental guidance recommended.

results.title: Return to Evercreech Junction. All change at Evercreech Junction. The friendly line to Burnham.
results.brief_description: For most passengers, a trip on the Somerset and Dorset, (affectionately known as the ‘Slow and Dirty’), meant seaside holidyas. It ran from Bath, up over Mendip Hills, before dropping down to Evercreech, the junction for Burnham-On-Sea, and onto Bournemouth. Before its unexpected closure in 1966, the Somerset and Dorset was filmed in colour by railway enthusiast, Ivo Peters of Bath. This is a vivid record of the steam age and the railwaymen who worked on the line

results.title: Rhino christmas
results.creator_credit: John Armstrong, Fiona Cochrane, Cochrane Productions and Armstrong
results.brief_description: It’s a hot and boringly predictable Christmas Day in the suburbs and Mott wishes it would snow. She’s sick of presents that are educational and of going to the beach with her new-age parents who meditate all day. But then weird things happen in this off beat fantasy.

results.title: Return from Witch Mountain
results.creator_credit: John Hough, Jerome Courtland, Ron Miller and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Sequel to “Escape to Witch Mountain” this family film is full of adventure and fantasy as Tia (Kim Richards) and her brother Tony (Ike Eisenmann), both who have supernatural powers, arrive on Planet Earth for a holiday. Dr Gannon (Christopher Lee) and his offsider Letha (Bette Davis) are trying to develop a mind-control device and when the evil Dr Gannon learns of Tony’s special powers, he kidnaps him, leaving it to Tia with her telepathic powers, and a motley gang of youngsters, to rescue Tony.

results.title: Rhine boatmen
results.brief_description: An account of the lives of the 40,000 men and women who live on the boats that trade up and down the Rhine, with some description of the river and its history.

results.title: Rhapsody in blue
results.creator_credit: Irving Rapper, Jesse L Lasky and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A story that is as enchanting as its central character, the legendary George Gershwin. Robert Alda plays the talented composer in this moving tribute to one of America’s premier musical artists. Following years of practice and an assortment of jobs, Gershwin experienced his first success with “Swanee” (sung in the film by the man who made it famous, the inimitable Al Jolson). Despite his ensuing accomplishments with hit songs and stage success, the musical genius yearned for something greater - to create a unique American music, combining European classics and popular songs. The realisation of Gershwin’s dream is what is perhaps his best known work - the fourteen minute piece entitled “Rhapsody in Blue”. In addition to its inspirational story, this film is musically uplifting, featuring a two-hour feast of classic Gershwin.

results.title: Rethinking rape (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is an in depth look at rape, particularly rape perpetrated by people known to the victim. In order to understand the high frequency of rape and its social causes, we must examine our cultural attitudes towards women, male/female relationships and rape itself. Six people of varying backgrounds, including a Rape Crisis Centre director, and a social psychologist, share their perspective’s on this topic.
